content: Retail is dead. Long live retail! After years of intense pressure from Amazon.com (AMZN), brick-and-mortar retail stocks like Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and TJ Max owner TJX (TJX) have rebounded. And the best mutual funds have been picking up shares.In addition to retail stocks, the best-performing mutual funds have also been putting money into the semiconductor, medical, transportation and banking sectors over the last three months.Seventeen top funds invested approximately $70.7 million in Macy's. Such buying has helped boost the department store chain's share price from a November low of 17.41 to a recent high of 41.33. Macy's ended Tuesday's trading at 39.96.Kohl's saw 16 of the best mutual funds scoop up an estimated $40.4 million worth of shares from March to May. Kohl's initially cleared a 67.10 double-bottom buy point on May 29. But the Wisconsin-based retail stock really blasted higher on June 4. Kohl's closed Tuesday's market session at 78.32, around 13% above the entry.TJX, Famous Footwear owner Calares (CAL) and building products retailer W.W. Grainger (GWW) have also been rising over the last few months. Grainger is extended from its recent breakout, while Calares is looking to retake a 36.10 buy point in an early stage flat base. The stock is currently 3% below that entry.Although Amazon didn't join its retail rivals on this month's list, its stock has been showing strength. Amazon is now out of buy range from its latest buy point.Apparel manufacturer PVH (PVH) did make the list and has just fashioned a new breakout. After reporting a 43% spike in earnings on May 3, the owner of leading brands like Tommy Hilfiger and Calvin Klein is now 1% above a 163.88 entry.Fellow clothing maker Oxford Industries (OXM) cleared an 84.42 buy point on June 1, and is currently trading 10% above that price.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseBoeing (BA), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Adobe Systems (ADBE) topped the latest list of new buys, with each pulling in over $1 billion in new investments.Fifty-three top funds invested approximately $1.9 billion in Boeing, while 69 funds put an estimated $1.2 billion into Adobe. Forty-one mutual funds laid down their chips in semiconductor giant Texas Instruments to the tune of just over $1 billion.Boeing lifted off past a 348.67 buy point in May and is currently 6% beyond that price. Adobe is around 35% above the 186.37 entry it cleared in early January, while Texas Instruments is working on a new base.Wolverine World Wide (WWW) led the list of stocks being sold with 22 net sellers (40 selling minus 18 buying). Despite that selling, the retailer of outdoor clothing and work footwear cleared a 33.92 recently and has now climbed out of buy range.Fellow retail stock Dillard's (DDS) was also near the top of the list with 16 net sellers (26 selling minus 10 buying). Like Wolverine, Dillard's has climbed sharply higher this month.Norfolk Southern (NSC), Harsco (HSC) and Chemed (CHE) also showed a significant number of net sellers.YOU MAY ALSO LIKE:Growth Stocks In Tech And Health Care: Fund Managers Like Their OutlookHow To Find Good Growth Stocks: A Mutual Fund Pro's Emotion-Free ApproachU.S. Treasuries Led Bond Funds Higher As 10-Year Yield Tumbled To 2.8%Which Stocks Make This List Of The Fastest Growing Companies?Looking For Breakout Stocks Like Nvidia? After a year of scorching revenue gains, teen-centric retailer Five Below (FIVE) now faces questions on whether there's life after fidget spinners.XThe small, propeller-like toys, held between one's thumb and finger and spun for enticingly long periods of time, met a hyperactive nation's fidgety needs last year. They also jolted Five Below's sales higher.When Wall Street sensed last spring and summer that the trend had reached its limit, the company's stock wavered during that time. But the good news for Five Below is that children also like fake slime. And they like foam toys called squishies, and things with mermaids on them, and grips that stick onto the backs of smartphones.They might also appreciate, as investors do, that the company plans to open around 125 U.S. stores this year, and could open hundreds more in the years ahead.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"Fads are important to Five Below," Dougherty analyst Jeremy Hamblin said. "But they're not the be-all, end-all."Those items — spinners, squishies and a broad supporting cast of other items sold for $5 or less — have made Five Below one of the few standouts in a retail industry grappling with an e-commerce upheaval. Its $5 price range has kept Amazon (AMZN) at bay, for now.Annual same-store sales have come in positive since 2007. The company's stock has sprinted 70% higher over the past 12 months. The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 97 out of a best-possible 99. Five Below also is targeting at least 20% net income and sales growth through 2020, which some analysts say is attainable. Shares were down 1.8% Friday afternoon amid a broad market sell-off to near 71.25.And as toy-store chain Toys R Us prepares to liquidate its U.S. stores, their loss could be Five Below's gain."The company today represents kind of a rare breed in retail, and that's a young, fast-growing, dynamic company that has lots of room to grow," BTIG analyst Alan Rifkin said. "Growth in retail is so rare that investors are grabbing stories like this and really running with it."Other discount retail chains, like Burlington Stores (BURL) and TJX Cos. (TJX), have tried to Amazon-proof themselves by using low-priced clothes and home products as a reason to actually go to stores. Once customers are in, they might find a marked-down item they like — and didn't know they wanted — and buy it. The retail industry calls that experience the "treasure hunt."Five Below's stores aim to do the same thing, but for a younger crowd."Consumers want experiences, and kids can be turned loose in the stores and it's a treasure hunt," Rifkin said of Five Below. "They can go around the store and put (items) in their basket that they want that they didn't really realize that they wanted before. It's tough to get that on the internet."Five Below's products are organized into eight different "worlds," or categories, like Room, Style, Sports, Tech and a section called Now, for trendy or seasonal items. The store offers headphones, phone cases, fitness gear, blankets and pillows. There's also heli balls — a ball with helicopter propellers attached to it — themed after Marvel superheroes. That wide array, Hamblin said, allows it to compete with a variety of different brick-and-mortar and online retailers.A KeyBanc analysis of products at Five Below and similar products at Amazon last year found that overall, Five Below's products were 53% less expensive. They offer "value that is not replicated" at the online retailer, KeyBanc said in a note to clients."We think that's a winning formula in the retail world," said KeyBanc analyst Brad Thomas. Thomas was among those who sensed the fidget spinner trend might have been ending last spring.That formula also includes plans to open up a whole lot more stores, following expansions into big states like Texas and Florida. The company opened 15 of them in California last year, with plenty of room to advance into San Francisco and San Diego. The company, which already has some 650 stores in 32 states, plans to open 125 stores this year, and says its store count could eventually reach 2,500.Further, Chief Executive Joel Anderson is a veteran of Toys R Us and Walmart (WMT). Its merchandising chief, Michael Romanko, has a team that has been able to sniff out trends early. The company also plans to open more distribution centers, including one in the Midwest in 2021."Which, to me, I interpreted as them saying 'We're gonna continue that 20% growth for even longer than what most investors had expected,'" Hamblin said. "And I think what's why you've seen the stock rally even though the market has come in."The analyst praise for Five Below comes as Toys R Us plans to shut down operations in the U.S. and liquidate its 735 U.S. stores. The company filed for bankruptcy protection last year, following mounting debt and competition from companies like Walmart and Amazon."We think in a world where Toys R Us no longer exists, or is soon to no longer exist, that brands will increasingly be looking to Five Below to grow their own revenue," Thomas said.But Hamblin notes that the fallout from big retail bankruptcies can be "notoriously difficult" to predict. The Toys R Us implosion could lead to a discount frenzy, pulling in bargain-seeking customers before the stores are vacated, temporarily thinning customer traffic at Five Below.As Five Below's stock climbs, analyst expectations have climbed with it. During fiscal 2017, the company delivered same-store sales gains that were as high as 9.3%. That number could be difficult to top this year. Analysts also worry the stock is getting expensive.The company, when it reported fourth-quarter earnings last month, also offered a tempered outlook for the year ahead, with full-year earnings-per-share and revenue forecasts coming in below expectations.As the company expands at a brisk pace, attracting qualified people to fill management and staff positions will remain a challenge. Hamblin said the company plans to have five distribution centers in 2021, up from two today. Growing such operations over a relatively short period of time could also be a challenge.RBC also notes that Five Below "sells predominantly 'discretionary' goods ('wants' vs. 'needs') and by extension is susceptible to risk of a protracted economic downturn" as customers spend more on the things they need. Any downturn could make a dramatic expansion plan look like a bad idea in hindsight.Even as the company grows, it isn't as ubiquitous as Walmart, Target (TGT) or Toys R Us. The company has launched an e-commerce segment that, while comprising a fraction of sales, could make it more recognizable."The e-commerce is helping increase the awareness of this company. That's a challenge too," Rifkin said. "There are people in many parts of the country that have never heard of the concept of Five Below."YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Five Below Beats Q4 Views But Guides 2018 Low; Burlington In Buy ZoneOllie's Bargain Outlet Shares Sink Late On Weak Revenue GuidanceJust Don't Do It: These 6 Top Stocks Teach Key Lesson In Market CorrectionRetail And E-Commerce News And Stocks To Watch

Gap (GPS) saw a positive improvement to its Relative Strength (RS) Rating on Tuesday, with an upgrade from 69 to 72. X When looking for the best stocks to buy and watch, one factor to watch closely is relative price strength.This exclusive rating from Investor's Business Daily identifies price movement with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The grade shows how a stock's price performance over the trailing 52 weeks compares to all the other stocks in our database. History reveals that the market's biggest winners often have an RS Rating of at least 80 in the early stages of their moves. See if Gap can continue to show renewed price strength and clear that threshold. See How IBD Helps You Make More Money In StocksGap is working on a consolidation with a 35.78 entry. See if it can break out in heavy trading. While EPS growth decreased in the company's most recently reported quarter from 20% to 17%, revenue grew 10%, up from 8% in the previous report. Gap earns the No. 19 rank among its peers in the Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories industry group. Lululemon Athletica (LULU), Burlington Stores (BURL) and TJX (TJX) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Strong earnings are expected for the banks and the S&P 500 index components generally. But investors will focus on whether that continues, especially as Trump trade…

Last week's rally, led by the Nasdaq composite, signaled the stock market is looking healthier. But which stocks and sectors are likely to lead?The FANG+ stocks of Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) generally have been performing well. Salesforce.com (CRM) and other software stocks have been winners. Payment stocks are a pocket of strength. Many retail names, from Lululemon (LULU) to TJX (TJX) have been strong. Energy stocks from Chevron (CVX) to Marathon Oil (MRO) are doing well, but are subject to the ups and downs of crude oil prices. Biotechs are trying to make a recovery, with Biogen (BIIB) skyrocketing Friday on positive Alzheimer's drug news.Meanwhile, chips are still well off their highs, a bad sign for any stock market rally. Financials are near 2018 lows, with JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) kicking off earnings season Friday.Dow futures rose 0.5% vs. fair value. S&P 500 futures climbed 0.5%. Nasdaq 100 futures were 0.5% above fair value. Keep in mind that Dow Jones futures and other overnight action doesn't always translate into actual trading in the next regular session.China's Shanghai composite roared 2.5% higher on Monday, after tumbling into a bear market in recent weeks. Hong Kong's Hang Seng advanced 1.3%. and Japan's Nikkei 1.2%. European markets showed modest gains intraday.During last week's holiday-shortened week, the stock market averages were volatile but ultimately rallied. The Nasdaq composite rallied 2.4%, the S&P 500 1.5% and the Dow Jones 0.8%. Friday's post-jobs, post-China tariffs rally was particularly significant. If you haven't already, you should read the latest Big Picture column.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe stock market came under pressure amid Trump trade war tariffs and threats over the past several weeks. President Donald Trump on Friday imposed tariffs on $34 billion worth of Chinese goods, quickly matched by Beijing. Trump also threatened tariffs on virtually all Chinese imports. But for now, Wall Street has decided the Trump trade impact has been priced into stocks.If you look at the Nasdaq composite over the last several months, the tech-heavy index looks like it broke out on June 1, rallied for a few weeks, then erased those gains before rebounding again last week from its 50-day moving average.The S&P 500 index and Dow Jones have been consolidating since late January, with the S&P 500 in somewhat better shape.Stocks, even top stocks, tend to track the broader stock market. But sector rotations into and out of China internets, software stocks and energy names have left many individual stock charts looking more volatile.Amazon stock and especially Netflix stock have been two of the biggest stock market winners in 2018. Facebook stock, after a scandalous spring, is at record highs, slightly extended from a buy point. Apple stock is in buy range from 179.04 double-bottom entry. The Dow Jones component has pulled back to its 50-day line and could be working on a new consolidation. Alphabet (GOOGL) is below a buy point after a low-volume breakout last month and hitting resistance at its old high.Software accounts for four of the top 10 groups in the 197 industries that IBD tracks. Two more are in the top 20.Buying and holding individual software stocks has been a challenge. Salesforce, the top stock in the No. 3-ranked enterprise software group, staged a low-volume breakout in early May, then promptly undercut the buy point. It didn't trigger a 7%-8% loss that would trigger an automatic sell. By the end of May, following quarterly earnings, Salesforce stock was back in buy range and is now modestly extended.Meanwhile, some stocks did trigger the 7%-8% loss sell rule, like Workday (WDAY) and Red Hat (RHT), while others round-tripped double-digit gains, such as Qualys (QLYS).Software Stocks To Watch: Okta (OKTA), an April 2017 cybersecurity IPO, is finding support at its 50-day moving average for the first time since a late April breakout. A solid gain in heavy volume could offer a buying opportunity. Alternatively, Okta could continue to consolidate for a few weeks, forming a new base and buy point.Collaboration software maker Atlassian (TEAM) broke out last October. Anyone holding Atlassian stock since then would be sitting pretty. Since then the stock has staged a few failed breakouts but still moved up, generally following its 50-day. Atlassian stock is once again finding 50-day support but needs at least another week to form a proper base.Lululemon Athletica and Canada Goose (GOOS) are among the trendy apparel retail stock that have boomed in 2018. Specialty discounters such as TJX are faring well too, with TJX rival Ross Stores (ROST) stock in buy range currently. Five Below (FIVE) and Dollar General (DG) are setting up near buy points.An improving jobs market and Trump tax cuts have fueled consumers' wallets and confidence. Most retailers also aren't that exposed to Trump trade wars with Europe, China and others.Energy stocks are tricky to play because they tend to rise and fall with crude prices. (Refiners tend to benefit from a wider "crack spread" between crude and gasoline prices.)EOG Resources (EOG), a recent IBD Stock of the Day, broke out in early May and ran up for a couple of weeks as crude futures rallied. But the EOG stock pulled back below the buy point and found support at the 50-day line in June as crude also backed off multiyear highs. EOG Resources, known as the "Apple of Oil," is setting up in a new base with crude hitting its best levels since 2014.Marathon Oil, another IBD Stock of the Day, also broke out in early May and ran up. Marathon Oil stock also pulled back to its 50-day line, but never undercut the buy point. Shares are now in a flat base within a base-on-base formation.Biogen shot up nearly 20% to 357.48 on Friday, racing toward a 370.67 cup-base entry. Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) also is closing in on a buy point. But both Biogen and Vertex Pharma have relative strength lines, while improving, that were in downtrends for several months. The relative strength line tracks a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 indexNotable biotech ETFs, including iShares Nasdaq Biotech (IBB) and the triple-levered Direxion Daily S&P Biotech Bull (LABU) also are approaching possible buy points, but with RS lines that have made much headway over the past year.Payment stocks have been a pocket of strength. Mastercard (MA) and Dow Jones component Visa (V) have been consolidating near record highs for a few weeks, finding support around their 50-day or 10-week lines. Square (SQ) has also been acting well. PayPal (PYPL) is close to record highs, but its recent breakout fizzled and its RS line has been going sideways since late 2017.Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.YOU MIGHT ALSO LIKE:These 5 Stocks Have RS Lines At Highs, Including This IPO BreakoutDon't Discount These 4 Top Stocks In Or Near Buy ZonesCybersecurity Leader Qualys Rebounds After Sell SignalHow Many Top Growth Stocks Are Forming Bases Now?IBD Stock Of The Day Nears New Buy Point After 46% Run In 2018

Retail industry groups dominated Monday's new high list, accounting for the top six groups and eight out of the top nine. Several retail names neared or cleared buy points, including Williams-Sonoma (WSM), Kohl's (KSS), Shopify (SHOP), Target (TGT) and Five Below (FIVE).Some hot retail stocks kept rising, including Lululemon Athletica (LULU), while struggling Walmart (WMT) rebounded.Shares of Amazon (AMZN) rose 1.45% Monday, remaining in a buy zone from either a 1,617.64 or 1638.20 entry. The top-rated IBD Leaderboard stock is hitting new highs, surpassing the last April gap-up following Amazon's blockbuster earnings.Retailers are benefiting from some headwinds — solid retail earnings, robust hiring and retreating oil prices — while largely avoiding headwinds from trade-war fears and a stronger dollar.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseHere's how key retail and e-commerce stocks are performing.Williams-Sonoma jumped 7.3% to 58.61 in Monday's stock market trading, clearing a first-stage cup-shaped base with a 56.48 buy point. Volume was well above normal, a sign that mutual funds and other big institutions are buying in bulk.The seller of home furnishings' beat-and-raise earnings report and growing e-commerce presence drove a late-May rally in its shares. The stock yields 3.1% and has recently joined IBD's Dividend Leaders list.The retailer's RS line bolted higher Monday as the stock continues to outperform the S&P 500 index.Kohl's surged 4.7% Monday to 71.56, hitting a three-year high and clearing a 13-week consolidation. The stock already topped a 67.10 shallow double-bottom base, but 69.58 offered an alternative entry. Meanwhile, volume was modestly above normal.Simultaneously, Shopify staged a breakout, jumping 4% to 156.90, above a 151.07 cup-with-handle entry. Shopify moved on low volume, though.Shopify is part of the enterprise software group, but its software platform helps retailers set up e-commerce sites.Kohl's RS Line is now at its highest level in the past year, as is Shopify's.Kohl's has been adapting to the rapidly shifting retail environment, carving out space in some stores for Amazon customers to return purchases.Target (TGT) shot up 4.9% to 76.35, closing on a flat-base buy point at 78.80. Five Below (FIVE) zoomed up 8.2% to 77.24, nearing its flat-base entry of 78.38.Five Below, the teen-friendly discount brand, reports earnings late Wednesday.Ross Stores (ROST) added 3% to 83.14. Its RS Line is rising but remains below the May high.Ross Stores and its off-price peers Burlington Stores (BURL) and TJX Cos. (TJX) all beat earnings views in recent reports.But Ross Stores sold off following its report, invalidating an 82.91 entry. It now has a new handle, with a new buy point at 84.67.The popularity of discount retailers continues to dent traditional malls even as they prove themselves Amazon-resistant.JPMorgan initiated coverage on Five Below Monday with an overweight rating and price target of 87.Canada Goose (GOOS) advanced 1.5%, setting an all-time high of 43.71 before pulling back. Fellow Canadian retailer Lululemon, which sells trendy yogawear, gained 2.3% as its post-earning rally continues.Canada Goose, whose e-commerce push drove 27% revenue growth in February, has not announced the date for its next report. The luxury apparel retailer sees a "massive" opportunity in China.YOU MAY BE INTERESTED IN:Retail Stock Five Below Expecting 120% Growth, Nears Buy Zone Of EarningsThis 99 Composite Rating Stock Skyrockets On Huge Earnings GrowthSell And Take Profits Or Hold? Here Are Several Guidelines To FollowHow To Find Great Growth Stocks: Learn To Spot The Flat Base, A Bullish Chart Pattern

TJX (TJX), the parent company of off-price chains T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods, reported strong Q4 results Wednesday and plans a significant increase in shareholder returns via dividends and buybacks.X Estimates: Fourth-quarter profit growth of 24% to $1.28 a share on 14% sales gains to $10.8 billion.Results: EPS of $1.37 on revenue of $11 billion and same-store sales growth of 4%.TJX  plans repatriate more than $1 billion in cash from its TJX Canada division in fiscal 2019 and is increasing its dividend 25% to 39 cents while also planning to repurchase approximately $2.5 billion-$3.0 billion of TJX stock during the fiscal year ending Feb. 2, 2019."Our business continues to generate tremendous amounts of cash and excellent financial returns," said CEO Ernie Herrman in a statement. "In addition, with the recent changes in U.S. federal tax law, we expect a significant increase in cash flow. A substantial use of this cash is reflected in our plan to increase our regular quarterly dividend and share buyback program while simultaneously reinvesting in the business."Stock: TJX shares jumped 7% to close at 82.68 on the stock market today. The stock had, like many others, breached its 50-day line in tandem with the broader market correction earlier in the month, dragging down shares. Rival Ross Stores (ROST), which reports next week, edged up 0.7%.IBD'S TAKE: By learning to use call options, investors can significantly reduce risk and capitalize on basing stocks that are making breakaway gains caused by earnings reports.The off-price space has been relatively resilient to the woes befalling specialty and department stores, particularly as some worry about online shoppers heading elsewhere. But it is not immune.In December, Wells Fargo analysts said Amazon (AMZN) was poised to surpass Macy's and TJX in clothing and shoe sales in 2017 by gross merchandise volume.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Macy's Stock Soars After Q4 Earnings, Comp Sales Beat; Outlook StrongDepartment Stores, Malls In 2018: Amazon Will Let You Live — For NowAmazon's Booming Apparel Business In Position To Pass Macy's, TJX

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. The earnings docket includes Lululemon Athletica (LULU), Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Burlington Stores (BURL) and Workday (WDAY), among a clutch of retail-oriented names. X Lululemon Athletica The yogawear retailer reports after the close. Estimates: Lululemon earnings to increase 41% to…

Big-box retailer Target (TGT) missed first-quarter earnings estimates Wednesday as the slow start to spring weather weighed on some sales.XEstimates: Earnings per share of $1.38, up 14%, on revenue of $16.43 billion, up 3%, according to Zacks Investment Research. Same-store sales are expected to notch a 2.8% gain, according to Consensus Metrix.  Results: EPS of $1.32 on sales of $16.56 billion. (Sales missed Thomson Reuters estimates.) Same-store sales rose 3%, with traffic up 3.7%. Digital sales climbed 28% vs. 29% in Q4.Management said that spending on its online efforts as well as price cuts and higher wages also hit margins.Outlook: Q2 EPS of $1.30-$1.50, with the midpoint above consensus views for $1.34, with comparable sales growth accelerating into the low to mid single digit range."Strong sales growth in our home, essentials and food & beverage categories offset the impact of delayed sales in temperature-sensitive categories, which accelerated rapidly in recent weeks as weather improved across the country," said Chairman and CEO Brian Cornell in a statement. "Additionally, our team is delivering excellent execution and guest service every day, and momentum in our traffic has accelerated in the second quarter."Stock: Shares tumbled 5.7% to close at 71.17 on the stock market today. They had been working on a 78.80 buy point from a flat base. Rival Walmart (WMT), which reported strong earnings and improved e-commerce growth last week, dipped 0.4% Wednesday.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseTarget's results follow an aggressive effort by the company to move into delivery and pick-up services to better compete with Walmart and Amazon.Over the past year, the company has acquired Shipt, and online delivery service. It has offered a drive-up app service in which items are brought to a customer's car. Target has also bought a transportation tech company to better handle delivery.Other retail stocks, like discounter Ross Stores (ROST), department-store Kohl's (KSS) and Amazon (AMZN), are setting up in bases or in buy range. Ross Stores reports on Thursday.Kohl's, however, crashed on Tuesday after the department-store chain signaled weaker same-store sales in the second quarter. Urban Outfitters (URBN) beat estimates late Tuesday.TJX Cos. (TJX), the parent of T.J. Maxx, jumped Tuesday after the company turned in a strong quarterly report.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Making Money In Stocks: How To Find The Correct Buy PointWhich Stocks Are Showing Rising Relative Strength?Retail And E-Commerce News And Stocks To Watch

Burlington Stores (BURL) reported fourth-quarter earnings, sales and EPS guidance above views early Thursday, pushing shares of the off-price apparel retailer higher.X Estimates: Earnings per share to increase 17% from a year ago to $2.09, on revenue of $1.882 billion, up 12%. Same-store sales are expected to rise 3%, according to Consensus Metrix.Results: Burlington Stores earned $2.17 a share on sales of $1.9 billion. Same-store sales jumped 5.9%.Outlook: The company expects adjusted EPS of $1.05-$1.09, above the consensus of 99 cents. Burlington Stores sees 9.5%-10.5% sales growth, slightly above views.Stock: Shares rose 5.8% to 122.84 in the stock market today, after dropping 5% on Wednesday. Rival off-price clothing chain Ross Stores (ROST), whose results late Tuesday also beat analyst expectations, dipped 0.2% Thursday.Shares of Ross tumbled Wednesday, after the off-price chain said it would raise its minimum wage to $11 an hour in what management said was an effort to "attract and retain talented associates." RBC analyst Brian Tunick, in a research note, also said that "lack of flow through of tax upside seems a bit disappointing to investors."Ross Stores also gave muted same-store sales guidance.TJX Cos. (TJX), which last week reported Q4 results that topped estimates and announced a dividend hike and share buybacks, climbed 3 cents on Thursday. TJX also slid on Wednesday.Use IBD's MarketSmith For Free Until March 11

See stocks near a buy point, get chart pattern recognition and run custom screens. Start NowBurlington over the years has become less about coats and cold weather, and attempted to offer better home products, beauty items and women's sportswear. The company has also shrunk and remodeled stores.Analysts have said off-price retailers like Burlington are more Amazon (AMZN)-proof than their more expensive rivals, in part because of what retail watchers call the "treasure hunt" experience they offer — in which bargain seekers visit a store with little sense of what they want to buy and hunt out attractive discounts.But in December, Wells Fargo analysts said Amazon's 2017 clothing and shoe sales, by gross merchandise volume, could pass those of TJX and Macy's (M).YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Dollar Tree Earnings, Sales, Outlook Weak; Costco Beats Revenue ViewsNordstrom Stock Sinks Late After Rejecting Nordstrom Family BidKohl's Tops But Shares Pressured; Nordstrom Sinks Late On EarningsMacy's Stock Soars After Q4 Earnings, Comp Sales Beat; Outlook Strong

Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) plunged as the retailer warned that first-quarter earnings will be at the lower end of guidance.The struggling fashion retailer expects EPS at the bottom of its forecast for 15-20 cents. Wall Street had forecast a 45% EPS drop to 18 cents per share, according to Zacks Investment Research.Comparable sales for the four weeks ended May 5 were flat vs. the same period ended May 6, 2017. The apparel retailer said this year's earlier Easter holiday cut sales by about 3 percentage points.Net sales for the four weeks ended May 5 were up 4% to $751.6 million. Q1 sales rose 8% to $2.63 billion, above views for $2.59 billion.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe company, whose other brands include Pink and Bath & Body Works, will report first-quarter earnings on May 23.L Brands stock dived 7.1% to 31.68 on the stock market today., hitting their worst levels in nearly seven years. The stock was as high as 63.10 on Dec. 26. Its relative strength line is at a near nine-year low.The stock boasts a dire IBD Composite Rating of 8 and an even worse Relative Strength Rating of just 5. Alarmingly, it has missed on revenue in four of the past six quarters.L Brands holds the No. 26 rank among its peers in the Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories industry group, which has been performing well Lululemon Athletica (LULU), Burlington Stores (BURL), Ross Stores (ROST) and TJX Companies (TJX) are the highest performing stocks in the group.Warehouse club chain Costco Wholesale (COST) also issued monthly sales results. April sales jumped 13.1% to $10.8 billion, with e-commerce accounting for 43% of that. Costco said the Easter calendar shift meant the four weeks benefited from an extra day.Costco dipped 0.3% to 195.45, working on a flat base with a 199.98 buy point.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Stock Market Bears Still Hibernate As This Asset Outperforms Equities Why Do 113 Top-Rated Funds Own Shares In This Breakout Cloud Stock? The stock market was mixed in afternoon trading Wednesday as early gains faded quickly.X The Nasdaq composite outperformed but was only up 0.2% after rising 0.8% intraday. The S&P 500 was up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.4%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking close to Tuesday's levels.Among the FANG names, Amazon.com (AMZN) hit another new high, rising 0.8%, after the company late Tuesday announced plans to acquire California-based video doorbell maker and home-security play Ring for around $1 billion.Elsewhere, Baidu (BIDU) added around 1% to 252.74 after the company announced plans to spin off iQiyi, a video streaming service in China similar to Netflix (NFLX).Separately, music streaming service Spotify filed for an IPO today that could raise as much as $1 billion, according to Reuters.In the stock market today, earnings reports dominated the headlines.Volume was heavy in Square (SQ) as shares rose more than 1% to 46.55. The catalyst was better-than-expected earnings and sales. Full-year guidance was mostly in line with expectations.Square is trying to clear a flawed cup-with-handle base with a 47.60 buy point. The base is flawed because the handle area corrected more than 20%. IBD research has shown that proper handles shouldn't pull back more than 15%.Meanwhile, Etsy (ETSY) soared 22% to 25.59, also on strong earnings. The stock gapped up over a 21.96 entry and opened at 24.02. Keep in mind it's OK to buy a stock when it gaps up in price; just try to buy as close to the open price as possible. Etsy operates an e-commerce website focused on handmade and vintage items. Goldman Sachs brought the company public in April 2015 at 16 a share.Track Top Stocks And Market Trends With Free IBD NewslettersIn the retail space, TJX Cos. (TJX) gapped up over an alternate entry of 81.56 on strong Q4 sales, plus news of a raised dividend and new share buyback program. Shares popped nearly 9% to 84. TJX is the parent of T.J. Maxx, Marshall's and HomeGoods.Inside the IBD 50, SVB Financial (SIVB) was a top gainer, up about 3%. It's been consolidating gains for 4-1/2 weeks as it gets support at the 10-week moving average.On the downside, Celgene (CELG) tanked 7% to a four-year low after the Food and Drug Administration rejected the company's application for ozanimod, a multiple sclerosis treatment.RELATED:How Celgene 'Gambled' On Ozanimod — And Why It Didn't Pay OffUpbeat Earnings Results Spark These Potential Leaders To New Highs Amazon's Ring Deal May Threaten These Security CompetitorsHere's How Square Sees Bitcoin Fitting Into Company's Future

U.S. stock indexes advanced early Wednesday as GDP matched the consensus expectation. Meanwhile, India's GDP came in at 7.2%, giving it the title for the world's fastest growing major economy.X The Nasdaq popped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and 0.4% respectively.Volume in the stock market today was up slightly on the Nasdaq.The second reading on fourth quarter GDP rolled in at 2.5%, matching the Street's consensus view. Recent GDP releases have sparked all-or-nothing reactions in the stock market. In the past 10 GDP releases not including Wednesday's report, the Nasdaq either rose or fell by more than 1% five times and rose or fell by 0.1% or less five times.India also reported its Q4 GDP this morning. The 7.2% spurt was higher than the 6.9% gain that analysts expected. India's growth surpassed China's 6.8% Q4 gain to grab the lead position among major economies.Barclays iPath India (INP) benchmark exchange traded fund is down 3% year to date after rising 41% last year.Among the India stocks trading on U.S. exchanges, three have Composite Ratings of 91 or better. The Composite Rating combines all five IBD ratings into a single number. A rating of 91 means the stock is in the top 9%.The three highly rated India stocks are HDFC Bank (HDB), which carries a 91 Composite Rating; tech services provider Infosys (INFY), which is rated 94; and outsourcer WNS Holdings (WNS), which is rated a best possible 99.WNS has shaped a base-on-base pattern with a 46.10 buy point.In the 30-component Dow Jones industrial average, Apple (AAPL) advanced 0.7%, staying just under a recent high. Boeing (BA) rose 1.8%, marking a new high.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, Retail-Apparel/Shoes scored strong gain. TJX Companies (TJX) gapped up 7% to a new high. Urban Outfitters (URBN) and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) notched solid gains but remain in their 5% buy zone.Chicago's purchasing managers index for February came in at 61.9, below the consensus figure of 65 and under the lowest estimate (62) in the range. The Chicago gauge measures both manufacturing and nonmanufacturing firms.The National Association of Realtors' pending home sales for January dived 4.7%, badly missing the consensus estimate for a 0.3% gain.RELATED:TJX Raises Dividend 25%Crocs Misses On Q4 Results

The major market averages gave up the day's early gains, reversing lower as they tried to recover from Tuesday's interest rate-driven sell-off in midday trade Wednesday. Top payment processor and IPO Leader Square (SQ) tried to break out past a potential buy point in the stock market today.X The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average turned red after giving up the morning's solid advances. Both fell about 0.2% apiece. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq traded 0.1% lower. Volume was tracking modestly lower on both the Nasdaq and NYSE compared with the same time period Tuesday.Among companies reporting earnings, Square turned unchanged after it briefly broke out past its 47.60 cup-with-handle entry. Late Tuesday, the payment processor reported solid earnings results. Shares had been up as much as 4.6% at its intraday high.Etsy (ETSY) soared 21% after easily topping the Street's targets. Shares broke out above a cup base's 21.96 entry on Feb. 21, but closed below the buy point and retreated lower over the next four trading days. Now, the stock is seeing renewed strength, as it jumps to new highs. The powerful breakaway gap provides a potential entry for investors around Wednesday's open price of 24.03.Veeva Systems (VEEV) was breaking out into new highs Wednesday after issuing bullish full-year earnings and sales guidance. The stock advanced 11% to move above two potential entries: a double bottom's 64.03 entry and a shorter double bottom's 63.10. The stock is extended from both levels.Shoemaker Crocs (CROX) plunged 13% after missing Q4 earnings targets. Shares broke out past a 14.57 flat-base buy point on Monday only to reverse lower Tuesday on heavy volume. The stock triggered the 7%-8% sell signal from the entry and pierced its 50-day line in huge turnover.Finally, Lowe's (LOW) sank over 6% after disappointing investors in its Q4 earnings release. The home-improvement retailer also gave weak profit guidance for 2018. The stock lost its battle at the 50-day line and has given up a large portion of its gains from an 82.84 cup-with-handle buy point.Get IBD's Market Prep And Tech Report Newsletters — For Free!Inside the IBD 50, Chinese solar name Daqo New Energy (DQ) dropped for a fifth straight day with a near-10% decline after its early Wednesday earnings release. The stock is about 30% off its high and now well below its 50-day line.RELATED:Are Top-Rated Stocks Like Alibaba, Tencent Ripe For The Picking?Salesforce, Crocs, Monster, Lowe's, TJX Lead Investing Action PlanWhich Stocks Make This List Of The Fastest-Growing Companies?The Cup Without Handle Can Also Yield Bullish Stock Breakouts

The S&P 500, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite broke monthly winning streaks and then sold off again to start March, as President Trump said he'll impose big, broad steel and aluminum tariffs and claimed "trade wars are good." Salesforce (CRM), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Workday (WDAY) and Square (SQ) were among techs reporting strong earnings.X Macy's (M) earnings topped, while Lowe's (LOW) missed. Auto sales generally fell more than expected. Samsung released an Apple (AAPL) iPhone X rival while Apple reportedly plans to launch three new handsets this fall.The S&P 500, Dow Jones and Nasdaq composite retreated despite generally strong earnings, with the Dow and S&P 500 erasing their 2018 gains and undercutting their 50-day lines. The Nasdaq did find support at that key area. President Trump on Thursday announced plans to impose steel and aluminum tariffs, lifting steel stocks but raising fears of retaliation by countries around the world. Trump doubled down, tweeting Friday that "trade wars are good, and easy to win." Jerome Powell, in his first congressional testimony as Fed chief raised concerns of four or more Fed rate hikes this year.Sign Up For Free IBD Newsletters: Market Prep | Tech ReportNew Fed Chairman Jerome Powell told Congress that he wants to continue the gradual rate hike policy. But he also noted that he and other Fed policymakers are raising their economic growth forecasts from the end of last year, sparking fears that the Federal Reserve will adopt more aggressive tightening. Meanwhile, the ISM manufacturing index pointed to the fastest factory expansion in nearly 14 years. But the Fed's favorite inflation gauge, the core PCE deflator, held at 1.5%, below policymakers' 2% target.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) blew past fiscal Q2 earnings estimates as a new product upgrade cycle kicked in. The cybersecurity firm and forecast April quarter profit and revenue above expectations.  Some analysts say Palo Alto has been gaining share in the security firewall market vs. rivals, although shifts in corporate spending to cloud computing infrastructure remains a concern. Management reiterated plans to introduce a broader security platform in 2018 that provides access to third-party technology. Palo Alto, with $2.4 billion in cash, could step up acquisitions. Fortinet (FTNT), a Palo Alto rival, hosted its first analyst day in tandem with a customer conference. Fortinet announced new, cloud-friendly software.Salesforce.com (CRM) delivered Q4 earnings, revenue, and bookings growth that analysts said puts it on a fast track toward the software giant's goal of  a $20 billion revenue run rate by 2022.  Salesforce.com noted an increase in large, multiproduct deals in industries such as financial services, health care and industrial. Management said it's prioritizing growth over profits in the near term, and guided to flat free-cash-flow margin. But for the April quarter, Salesforce forecast EPS of 43-44 cents on revenue of $2.93 billion vs. consensus of 37 cents on sales of $2.91 billion.U.S. auto sales weakened further in February. General Motors (GM) and Ford (F) reported 6.9% drops year over year, worse than feared. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) sales slid 1.4%, beating views. But Toyota (TM) grew sales nearly 5%. Automakers held back on incentive spending and cut car production, experts said. Auto stocks fell, in large part on Trump's vow to impose steel-and-aluminum tariffs, which would hike automakers' costs.Splunk (SPLK) reported Q4 revenue jumped 37% to $419.7 million, beating the consensus of $391 million, with earnings edging views as the big data analytics software company's security business picked up momentum. Billings came in 12% ahead of consensus and grew 44% year-over-year. Splunk raised fiscal 2019 revenue guidance by 5% to $1.625 billion. Splunk earlier in the week acquired security firm Phantom for $350 million. Splunk jumped 9.3% Friday.Samsung introduced its Galaxy S9 smartphones and took aim at the Apple (AAPL) iPhone X handset. The Galaxy S9 and S9 Plus are priced significantly below the iPhone X and feature displays and cameras that Samsung believes are superior to those on its main rival flagship phone. Apple is expected to introduce three handsets in September: OLED models with 5.8- and 6.5-inch displays and an LCD model with a 6.1-inch screen. Wall Street firm Canaccord Genuity estimates that Apple raked in 87% of the smartphone industry's profit in the fourth quarter, despite selling about 18% of total units. Samsung sold slightly more units, but accounted for only 10% of industry profits. Meanwhile, overall smartphone sales dipped in 2017.Walmart (WMT), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and Kroger (KR)-owned Fred Meyers said they won't sell firearms to people under the age of 21. Dick's Sporting Goods said its would stop selling assault-style rifles and high-capacity magazines in the wake of the Parkland shooting on Feb. 14. Walmart stopped selling high-powered rifles in 2015. Delta Air Lines (DAL), Hertz (HTZ) and insurer MetLife (MET) cut ties with the National Rifle Association amid a backlash for offering members discounts but FedEx (FDX) said it will continue to honor its discount.Comcast (CMCSA) is expected to make a $31 billion cash bid for U.K.-based Sky within weeks. Walt Disney (DIS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA), which owns 39% of Sky, are expected to raise their offer for all of the satellite TV broadcaster. Disney in December agreed to buy Fox's Sky stake, film studio and other assets. Shares in Comcast, Disney and Rupert Murdoch's Fox fell on bidding war fears. Some analysts questioned Comcast's interest in a satellite TV firm, given falling subscribers at AT&T (T)-owned DirecTV and Dish Network (DISH). If Comcast buys a controlling stake in Sky, analysts say buying a wireless firm such as T-Mobile US (TMUS) would be less likely near-term.Square (SQ) topped adjusted Q4 earnings views and forecast full-year 2018 profit in line with expectations as it invests in new products and expands overseas. Square in November began testing a Bitcoin exchange so that Square Cash app users could buy and sell the cryptocurrency. Square said Bitcoin had an "immaterial" impact on Q4 results, but noted that it's holding a "small amount" of the cryptocurrency on its balance sheet to help future transactions using its Square Cash app. Square shares rose modestly, just below a buy point.Workday (WDAY) reported Q4 adjusted profit and revenue that topped views. Workday has expanded from human capital management products into financial software. Workday announced that it had closed two Fortune 500 financials deals in the fourth quarter.Macy's (M) reported a surprise fourth-quarter same-store sales increase and gave a bullish outlook, citing strong consumer spending and a "disciplined" approach to discounts. Kohl's (KSS) beat on earnings and sales and guided up on full-year profit. But, as a test, Kohl's plans to lease space in five to 10 stores to German discount grocer Aldi. Nordstrom's same-store sales and revenue topped estimates, a week after Reuters reported that the Nordstrom family group was putting the finishing touches on an offer to go private. But earnings missed. J.C. Penney (JCP) topped earnings views, but missed on sales and same-store sales. Macy's and Nordstrom rallied on earnings; Kohl's and J.C. Penney fell.The SEC launched a wide-ranging probe into initial coin offerings, issuing subpoenas to Overstock.com (OSTK) and scores of technology companies and advisors in the digital currency market. The SEC is seeking information on ICO sales and presales. Shares of Overstock.com and Kodak (KODK), which plans to issue a KodakCoin, fell. Meanwhile specialty payments provider Fleetcor (FLT) has announced it will test the use of cryptocurrency Ripple as a tool to help business clients make international payments to suppliers and employees. Bitcoin reclaimed the $11,000 level.Better-than-expected earnings was not enough to stop LGI Homes (LGIH) and Toll Bros. (TOL) from selling off Tuesday. LGI Homes, which focuses on entry-level homes, reported a 42% EPS gain as revenue swelled 71% to $405 billion. Affordable-luxury homebuilder Toll Bros.' EPS was up 50% as revenue jumped 28% to $1.175 billion. Builder stocks have been under pressure amid concerns over rising material costs and potential interest rate increases.Lowe's (LOW) tumbled after the home improvement chain missed on earnings and gave weak full-year profit guidance. Floor & Decor (FND), an IBD 50 flooring retailer, which came public in April 2017,  saw adjusted earnings per share swell 73% to 19 cents, while sales increased 40% to $389.5 million. Same-store sales were also up by 24.4%. But its shares still retreated.Boeing (BA) and the Trump administration have reached a $3.9 billion, fixed-price informal deal for two Air Force One planes. Air Force wanted a fixed-price contract that would make Boeing responsible for any extra costs. President Trump had threatened, tweeting in late 2016 that "costs are out of control." Meanwhile, Boeing will take a 51% stake in a joint venture with Brazil's Embraer (ERJ), according to Brazilian media.Crude oil futures fell 3.6% to $61.25 a barrel as more shale producers raised 2018 production forecasts. EOG Resources (EOG), RSP Permian (RSPP), Sanchez Energy (SN), Carrizo Oil & Gas (CZO) are more bullish on output with oil above $60. But EOG Resources, Sanchez and Carrizo stocks tumbled on concerns over capital spending and other costs. RSP Permian rallied.General Electric (GE) warned of potential new penalties tied to a legacy subprime mortgage lending unit, weeks after revealing two SEC probes related to contract asset accounting and an insurance reserve charge. It will lower 2016 EPS by 13 cents and 2017 EPS by 16 cents, on new accounting rules. The troubled industrial giant is promising more transparency. Warren Buffett, CEO of Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), said he was "staggered" by GE's financial lapses but would buy GE businesses if the price was right.Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile (SQM), Albemarle (ALB) and other lithium miners tumbled on a Morgan Stanley report that surging output could cause prices to crater almost in half by 2021. Tesla (TSLA) and other automakers are big buyers of lithium for electric car batteries. Albemarle topped fourth-quarter earnings and revenue estimates later in the week, while SQM met EPS views while beating on sales.Microchip Technology (MCHP) will acquire Microsemi (MSCC) for $68.71 a share, with an enterprise value of $10.15 billion.Weight Watchers International (WTW) beat Q4 estimates. EPS vaulted 95% to 37 cents as revenue grew 17% to $313 million. The Oprah-backed weight-loss company offered a strong outlook, with its 2018 EPS guidance of $2.40-$2.70 topping analyst views.Booking Holdings (BKNG), formerly Priceline, jumped 7% after the online travel company reported fourth quarter results that beat on the top and bottom line, as did its outlook.Amazon (AMZN) reportedly will pay over $1.2 billion to buy Ring, maker of a smart doorbell that streams audio and visual to phones. Amazon is building on its smart-home product footprint in a race to be the market and mind share leader.JD.com (JD) missed on fourth-quarter earnings, with marketing costs soaring as the Chinese online sales giant competes with Alibaba (BABA). JD shares tumbled 5.2% Friday.Spectrum Brands Holdings (SPB), maker of Kwikset door locks and George Foreman grills, is merging with its top shareholder HRG Group (HRG). The deal is valued at $10 billion. HRG will wind down.Shares of Etsy (ETSY) soared, following a strong fourth-quarter earnings report that convinced skeptics the arts and crafts online retailer's new initiatives to expand sales are working.China-based Baidu (BIDU) plans a U.S. IPO for its Netflix (NFLX)-like video streaming service, iQiyi, aiming to raise $1.5 billion.Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) reported better-than-expected holiday-quarter results and raised its targets for the current year, sending its shares higher. Its appliance sales rose 21% year over year as it took advantage of problems at Sears.Chipmaker Analog Devices (ADI) topped Wall Street's sales and earnings estimates for its fiscal first quarter and guided above views for the current quarter. But its shares sold off on concerns about rising inventories.Disappointing Q1 guidance sent shares of children's apparel retailer Carter's (CRI) plunging below their 50-day line, even though holiday-season EPS topped views and full-year outlook compared well to consensus.Off-price giant TJX (TJX), parent of T.J. Maxx and Marshalls, hiked its dividend by 25% to 39 cents and plans for $2.5 billion to $3 billion in share buybacks. The company reported a solid Q4 beat.Monster Beverage (MNST) missed fourth-quarter earnings and sales estimates, sending shares lower.Brazilian iron ore producer Vale (VALE) reported fourth-quarter earnings of 36 cents a share, topping estimates by 13 cents. Full-year earnings and sales showed healthy gains, but quarterly results trailed the year-ago period as the rebound in iron ore prices lost momentum, at least temporarily.

Dow Jones futures were essentially flat vs. fair value.Square earned 8 cents a share, up 60% vs. a year earlier, beating views by 1 cent, according to Zacks Investment Research. Shares fell 1.4% to 45.91 during Tuesday's stock market trading.Square is close to a cup-with-handle buy point of 47.60, though the stock's recent climax-like run in late 2017 is troublesome.The relative strength line, which tracks a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index, is not at highs but is already above the peak of the handle.The online retailer of arts and crafts and handmade goods earned 36 cents a share adjusted, crushing views for 8 cents and reversing a year-earlier 19-cent loss. Etsy revenue climbed 24% to $136.2 million, the third straight quarter of accelerating growth and also topping.Etsy initially struggled to grow in the ever-looming presence of Amazon but has found its footing.Shares shot up 15% to 24.18 in late trading. That suggests that the stock will blast above a 21.96 buy point at Wednesday's open.The stock's RS line is not far from recent highs and is likely to move into new-high ground if the stock surges Wednesday.The cloud-based human resources and financial services software maker retreated nearly 3% in late trading after hitting a record high intraday, closing up 0.3% to 128.21.Workday earned 28 cents a share, beating views by 7 cents. Workday sees 2018 subscription revenue up 27% to 28%.Heico earned 45 cents a share, up 25% vs. a year earlier and beating views by 6 cents. Stocks opened to moderate gains Wednesday, as early earnings news and positive fourth-quarter consumer price and spending revisions fueled early gains.X Art market site Etsy (ETSY) notched a breakout at the open, as an Amazon.com (AMZN) acquisition and a pending spin-off from China-based Baidu (BIDU) also helped energize early trade.The Nasdaq Composite popped 0.4% at the start of trade as Apple (AAPL) and three of four FANG stock tech leaders posted early gains. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped almost 0.4%, with Boeing (BA) and Verizon (VZ) leading the index. The S&P 500 opened 0.3% higher, as heavy early losses from Lowe's (LOW), Celgene (CELG) and Discovery Communications (DISCA) held back early action.Markets across Asia took a beating Wednesday as investors reacted to comments made Tuesday by U.S. Fed chief Jerome Powell and to weaker-than-expected manufacturing data out of China. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dived 1.4%, the Shanghai Composite slipped 1% and, in Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dumped 1.4%.Stocks in Europe turned mixed afternoon trade. The CAC-40 in Paris and London's FTSE 100 both reversed early losses and clung to fractional gains.The Commerce Department kept its estimate for fourth-quarter GDP growth essentially unchanged, at 2.5%, vs. its initial estimate of a 2.6% gain. The number was what economists largely expected. Wednesday's report also eased the price growth estimate a notch, to 2.3%, down from 2.4%— that was below expectations for no change, and eased some pressure on interest rates. Consumer spending was unchanged, up 3.8%, above forecasts for 3.7% growth, also a positive.Kingsbury International releases its Chicago Purchasing Managers Index at 9:45 a.m. ET, followed by January pending home sales data from the National Association of Realtors and the Energy Information Administration's weekly oil inventory estimates.Verizon and Boeing each jumped more than 1% to take an early lead among Dow Jones stocks. Verizon has been struggling to regain support at its 10-week moving average since Feb. 21. Boeing is extended, in a profit taking zone above a September breakout.Etsy rocketed 21% higher after reporting a fourth-quarter earnings surge of 179% and a third straight quarter of revenue growth acceleration late Tuesday. Total value of goods sold during the quarter topped $1 billion for the first time. The high-volume gain left shares beyond buy range above a 21.96 buy point in a second-stage cup base.Weight Watchers (WTW) swept up 7% after reporting a 63% earnings gain and a 16% rise in revenue, both above consensus views. Management also raised its full-year earnings guidance to well above expectations, and announced it's shifting its focus from diet to overall health, aiming to become "a partner in health and wellness." The stock is extended, in a profit-taking zone after clearing a cup-with-handle base in January.Booking Holdings (BKNG) grabbed an 9% opening gain. The travel deals site formerly known as Priceline Group reported a stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter performance late Tuesday. The breakout gain put shares in a buy range above an 1984.10 buy point in a first stage cup-with-handle base.Daqo New Energy (DQ) dropped 4% higher in early trade. The China-based polysilicon maker's fourth-quarter sales and earnings cleared analyst targets by wide margins. The stock has been battling resistance at its 10-week moving average, as it attempts to build the right side of a possible base.On the downside, Lowe's dive 8% after a mixed fourth-quarter report showed fourth-quarter earnings and full-year earnings guidance below consensus estimates. Shares have been fighting since early February tbayryo climb back on their 10-week moving average and build the right side of a possible base.Amazon.com confirmed late Tuesday it was preparing to acquire video security and doorbell maker Ring, in a deal reportedly worth more than $1 billion. The deal for the Santa Monica, Calif.-based outfit would be Amazon's second-largest to date, and would bolster Amazon's efforts to expand home security measures related to package theft. Amazon shares are extended, and in a profit-taking zone after clearing a flat base in January.News reports said European Union regulators were set to approve, with conditions, the $62.5 billion acquisition of U.S.-based Monsanto (MON) by Germany's Bayer (BAYRY). Monsanto shares rose 0.6%.China-based search engine Baidu traded 0.8% higher after its streaming video services unit iQiyi registered on Tuesday to spin out in a U.S. IPO. The streaming service, which offers both free and subscription-based content, aims to raise $1.5 billion. It will trade on the Nasdaq as IQ.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Inflation Fears Jolt Stocks; Here's The Silver Lining This Top Stock Just Triggered A Sell Signal On Weak GuidanceShale Leader Crushes Views, Hikes Dividend, Sees $1 Billion Capex BumpSalesforce, Crocs, Monster, Lowe's, TJX Lead Investing Action Plan

So much for Monday's bullish session for the stock market. Major stock indexes ended with sharp losses Tuesday as Fed Chair Jerome Powell testified on Capitol Hill about the health of the economy and the path of interest rates. Wall Street seemed to focus on Powell's outlook for stronger growth, which put inflation fears on the front burner again. But overall,…

Storefront retail has become a dreary landscape, and even more littered with dismal news after a trying holiday season. Holiday-quarter reports showed weak foot traffic and soft, if not declining, same-store sales. Consumers aren't buying less, but it has become the conventional wisdom that Amazon.com (AMZN) is murdering all but the best malls, and that young people prefer experiences to tangible products…

Department stores such as Macy's (M), J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) sold off Monday on little news, as investors continue to lower their prospects for traditional retailers as shoppers increasingly shift to Amazon.com (AMZN) and other e-commerce sites.Macy's fell 3.8% to 29.37 on the stock market today, trading at its lowest levels since early February, when takeover buzz began.Kohl's sank 4.8% to 38.56, setting a seven-month low intraday.J.C. Penney retreated 2.3% to 5.85, hitting a five-year low. Regional department store operator Dillard's tumbled 4.5% to 49.79, also hitting its worst levels since early 2012.IBD's Retail-Department Store group, rated dead last out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks, was the biggest losers in Monday's session. Macy's and Kohl's were among the very worst performers on the S&P 500 index Monday.Department stores are working hard to try to be viable, emphasizing their online presence. But Amazon is grabbing a huge share of online sales growth and boasts bigger shipping discounts than even major retailers. Brick-and-mortar chains hope to better-leverage physical stores for online pickups and returns. But at the same time they are slashing their store count. That lowers costs, but calls into question the very omnichannel model they are trying to use to battle Amazon.IBD'S TAKE: Despite their brick-and-mortar woes, traditional retailers are seeing big online sales gains, but from very low levels.Target (TGT) fell intraday to a five-year low, though the retailer closed up 8 cents to 54.37. Target has been lumped in with department stores, especially after its weak Q4 earnings report and guidance.Amazon, for its part, rose 0.55% to 856.99. Amazon is still in buy range from an 821.75 entry and is setting up in a four-weeks-tight pattern with an 860.76 buy point.As for other retailers, Wal-Mart (WMT) isn't doing as badly as some of its rivals. Wal-Mart saw sharp online sales growth over the holidays, with U.S. same-store sales rising. Wal-Mart is re-emphasizing lower prices, a push that's squeezing everyone from Macy's to Target to grocers such as Kroger (KR).Wal-Mart shares closed up 0.1% to 59.98 Monday. But Wal-Mart stock is below its 200-day line and its relative strength line shows the retail giant is an S&P 500 laggard.Off-price retailers such as TJX (TJX) and Burlington Stores (BURL) are near highs, but they too retreated Monday, down 1.3% and 2%, respectively.RELATED:Macy's, Costco, Kohl's And Other Retailers Are Getting SlammedRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps BoomingTarget Dives To 2014 Levels: 'We're Slow And Have Too Much Inventory'J.C. Penney To Close 130-140 Stores After Mixed Q4, Comp Sales Drop

Off-price retailer Burlington Stores (BURL) reported fourth-quarter results that topped forecasts Thursday and gave strong 2017 guidance, sending shares soaring to a record high.Estimates: EPS to rise 13% to $1.69 as revenue grows 8% to $1.66 billion.Results: Adjusted EPS climbed 19.5% to $1.78 on a 9% revenue gain to $1.69 billion. Same-store sales grew 4.6%.Outlook: Q1 EPS of 67-70 cents, with the midpoint below consensus of 70 cents, on sales growth of 5%-6%, below consensus for 6.5%, with comp sales up 1%-2%. Full-year EPS of $3.77-$3.87, with the midpoint above consensus for $3.77, on sales growth of 7.5%-8.5%, with the midpoint above consensus for 7.7%, with comp sales up 2%-3%.Stock: Shares shot up 6.7% to 94.59 on the stock market today, hitting a record high. The stock cleared an 81.10 buy point from from a cup-with-handle base last month.Off-price retailers are the teacher's pets of the retail space. TJX (TJX), Ross Stores (ROST) and Burlington frequently get Wall Street call-outs for thriving amid a dismal brick-and-mortar environment that has knocked about Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and other department stores, as well as many specialty apparel retailers.The bargain-hunt nature of digging through discount racks is said to give off-pricers some Amazon (AMZN) resistance; stores like Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT), by contrast, are beefing up their digital capabilities to handle the threat.TJX climbed 1.2%, hitting its best level since mid-August intraday. Ross Stores shares rose 1.5%, retaking their 50-day line.RELATED:TJX Had Happy Holiday Quarter, Hikes Dividend, Sets BuybackBurlington Rebrands Itself To Show It's More Than Just Coat

The retail trade has become a realm of mass layoffs and hair-trigger stock sell-offs, driven primarily by the rising dominance — part real, part perceived — of Amazon.com (AMZN). One retail segment that has so far been left largely unscathed: discount retailers such as dollar stores and off-price chains. But Amazon quietly recently launched a "$10 & Under With Free Shipping" category.…

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week.
