With 96% of the S&P 500 reported, the second quarter earnings season is all but complete. Since last week, only three new companies have reported. The remaining unreported companies, such as Bausch & Lomb (BOL) and Altera (ALTR), have delayed their fillings due to options-related accounting and other factors.

To recap the quarters results, there was healthy overall earnings growth along with a sky-high positive to negative analyst surprise ratio. The median company grew earnings over 12% during the quarter. To keep these numbers in perspective, remember that this year all companies must fully expense employee stock options, while last year it was up to the company. Thus the 12.3% growth actually understates the true economic growth by a few percent. The Energy sector was far and away the earnings leader, posting an amazing 65.6% median growth rate, quarter-over-quarter. The next two leading sectors, industrial and telecom, lagged well behind with growth rates of 18.6% and 16.9% respectively. For the quarter, positive earnings surprises have outnumbered negatives by nearly four to one.

Looking forward to the third quarter, EPS growth is expected to slow to just over 9%. Much of this slowdown is due to lower comparable commodity prices in the energy sector, which is expected to post a still enviable median growth rate of 25%. Utilities and Tech are also expecting a slow down, with growth estimates at 7.8% and 5.7% respectively. Only the materials and telecom sectors are expected to record more favorable third-quarter growth rates.

For the full year, median EPS growth is expected to come in at 11.5%. This is unchanged from last week but up slightly from the 11.2% seen two weeks ago. The growth leader should be, as expected, the energy sector. The materials and industrials sectors should also post solid year over year EPS comparisons at 23.3% and 16.4%, respectively. The years laggard is expected to be Utilities, with an estimated year-over-year growth rate of 3.2%. Continued downward estimate revisions have plagued the utilities sector across the board, as is the case with companies like Progress Energy (PGN) and Nisource (NI).

Market Cap versus Total Earnings

When making investment decisions, growth should always be looked at in conjunction with how much you are paying for a stock. Thus, it makes sense to look at the total earnings expected for a sector, relative to that sectors total market capitalization. This is basically a variation on looking at the P/E.

The chart below shows the share of total earnings for 2005, 2006 and 2007, as well as the share of total market capitalization for each sector (the final bar shown). Since the S&P 500 is a market cap weighted index, this is the same as its index weight. On the chart below, the difference between the sizes of the first three bars shows if a sector is gaining or losing earnings share. The difference between the final bar and the first three bars shows if the sector is selling for an above or below market P/E. If the final bar is smaller than the other bars, the sector is selling for a below market P/E. However, as opposed to just showing the sector P/Es, it also shows the relative importance of the sectors to the overall index.

Clearly the Financials are the biggest influence on the market, with a weight of 21.7%, it has more influence than the Consumer Staples, Utilities, Materials and Telecom sectors combined. However, that sector is also relatively cheap on an earnings basis, and thus serves to hold the overall P/E of the index down. In other words, Financials deserve to be the biggest influence on the market, since they contribute 26.3% of the total expected earnings for 2006, or more than the total earnings of the Tech, Industrial and Utility sectors combined.

Energy looks to be under represented in its influence on the market since it is expected to provide 14.6% of total earnings for 2006, but represents only 8.9% of the total market capitalization of the index. While its earnings share is currently expected to decline to 14% in 2007, even on this basis it is still much cheaper than the overall market. Clearly at 8.9%, Energy is far from being in a bubble phase. Frankly, I find the notion of an Energy stock bubble to be absurd. Even though the NASDAQ is at only 40% of its early 2000 peak, a much stronger case could be made for Tech being bubbly than for Energy.

Looked at another way, Energy will provide 21.5% of the total incremental earnings in the S&P 500 this year, while that is down from the 42.3% of the total it provided last year, it is still far above its weight in the index. In more conventional terms, the Energy sector is trading for 9.2x 2006, and 8.8x 2007 earnings. Tech on the other hand is trading for 21.6x 2006 and 18.4x 2007 earnings. The S&P is trading for 15.2x and 13.8x, respectively. The second chart below shows the sector P/Es ranked from lowest to highest based on total 2006 earnings.
